reviews.review_msg: Becky's classes are life changing. I honestly mean it, they should be mandatory for everyone in every program. I cannot recommend her as a prof enough. One warning: it is impossible to know what she will love or hate in an assignment or project, but normally if you put a lot of care and work into it- you will be rewarded.

most kind, most loving, most accepting, most non-judgemental, most inspiring professor at SFU. Will always allow you to rework your pieces if you want a higher grade, and will always email back promptly. Becky always invites questions/comments in class. Becky is extraordinarily hilarious and inviting. By week two, we were all being vulnerable. LOVE

An awesome prof!! Wanted her students to do the best that they could and not be overworked. Class discussions were always welcomed and every voice got heard without judgement. She was open to learning new things about the topics from the class which is always a sign of a great prof!! If you have the opportunity to take a class with her, do it!

I admire Rebecca as a sociology professor. She is very passionate about her own research and connects it to the actual course material. She is relatable and encourages her students to grow, and that's important in one's university experience. Participation is not graded harshly at all. Definitely learned a lot from the 2 courses I've taken with her

I loved Rebecca! Her lectures were great - well-organized and well-thought-out although they could get a bit off-topic sometimes (but I like that kind of thing). It really helped in thinking outside the box on the topics we were talking about. It does have a large group project at the end, so be wary if you hate group work. Discussions were amazing

Lectures were riveting yet accessible and dialogue-based. Always made sure that every voice in the class was given a platform without letting things digress too much. Her empathetic & cerebral approach to teaching was astounding and she managed to transform the classroom into a genuinely safe space. I cried when I handed in my last assignment!!

The course itself is very straight forward. Professor Yoshizawa gives interesting examples, jokes often, always available outside of the class. Even though the course requires a textbook, professor summarizes and shares information in her lecture slides. However, she does not post the lecture slides so it's better to attend the lectures.

She's not only understanding, considerate, and generally a positive and wonderful person, she's also brilliant? Very coherent and engaging lectures with wonderful discussions. She does have a bit of a hard time keeping the discussions from running long, so if you tend to talk a lot maybe hold back and let other people get a word in! ;)
